main event: On March 12, 1952, a bright light was observed flying at a high rate of speed from NW to SE over Columbus, Ohio. The object was described as a long, shiny, wingless object tapering from a circular north to a point in the south, traveling at an extremely high speed. Several air force personnel, including a pilot and his instructor, observed the object through binoculars for 2 to 3 minutes.
interesting points: Multiple air force personnel observed the bright light, including a pilot and his instructor on a training mission.
The object was described as long, shiny, wingless, and traveling at an extremely high speed from NW to SE.
The object was visible for 2 to 3 minutes and was observed through binoculars by several airmen at Lockbourne Air Force Base.
The sighting was also reported by a newspaper reporter, who mistook the object for a D-45 aircraft, causing the vapor trail to appear reddish.
The phenomenon observed was reported at 5:15 p.m. on March 12, 1952, and witnessed by multiple credible individuals.
result: The sighting was initially believed to be an unidentified aerial phenomenon, but subsequent investigation revealed it to be a D-45 aircraft, causing the vapor trail to appear reddish.
sighted object: Long, shiny, wingless object tapering from a circular north to a point in the south, traveling at an extremely high speed
witnesses: Several air force personnel, including a pilot and his instructor, and a newspaper reporter
